message_1: In modal logic, suppose we have a set of possible worlds {w1, w2, w3} and a proposition p that is true in all worlds except for w2. What is the modal formula that expresses "p is necessarily true"?
message_2: In modal logic, the modal formula that expresses "p is necessarily true" is denoted by the symbol "□p" (read as "box p" or "necessarily p"). However, in the given scenario, p is not true in all possible worlds (it is false in w2). Therefore, it is not correct to say that p is necessarily true in this case. If p were true in all possible worlds, then the modal formula □p would accurately represent "p is necessarily true."
